speaker: MRS. MCALPIN
line: Your turn. Jack? Honey? Are you still feeling sick?

speaker: PRIVATE MCALPIN
line: What’s the matter with you? Can’t you hear the baby is crying?

speaker: MRS. MCALPIN
line: How ‘bout some cereal, Honey?

speaker: MRS. MCALPIN
line: You were having those awful dreams again last night.

speaker: PRIVATE MCALPIN
line: I didn’t sleep long enough to be dreaming.

speaker: MRS. MCALPIN
line: I want you to go to the doctor. Find out what’s wrong. Will you do that?

speaker: PRIVATE MCALPIN
line: I’d just like to eat my breakfast in peace! Do you think that’s possible.

speaker: MRS. MCALPIN
line: Jack, what is it?!

speaker: MULDER
line: Private John McAlpin-- one of the few, the proud... the dead. Last week he wrapped his car around a tree. Died on impact.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Drug and alcohol tests came back negative. Car shows no evidence of brake, steering or any other mechanical failure.

speaker: MULDER
line: The military is calling it a suicide—They’re especially concerned because it’s the second one in as many weeks.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Both at the same base?

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah, except that it's not exactly a base. Flip to the back. The Marines were all stationed at the Folkstone processing center in North Carolina. More than 12,000 refugees waiting for asylum from Uncle Sam.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Wasn't there a riot there about a month ago?

speaker: MULDER
line: A ten year old boy was killed but the uh, details of his death were never released.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Why did the military contact us?

speaker: MULDER
line: They didn't. Mrs. McAlpin contacted the Bureau when the military refused her request to investigate her husband's death further.

speaker: SCULLY
line: She doesn’t believe it was suicide.

speaker: MULDER
line: There.

speaker: MULDER
line: This is the tree that stopped Private McAlpin's car. State police reported there's graffiti on the bark.

speaker: SCULLY
line: It looks like some kind of ritual symbol.

speaker: MULDER
line: Most of the refugees at Folkstone are Haitian.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mrs. McAlpin believes voodoo was behind her husband's death?

speaker: MULDER
line: Mrs. McAlpin doesn't believe her husband killed himself. She wants to know who did.

speaker: MRS. MCALPIN
line: Jack used to tell these jokes. Well, they were pretty dumb, I guess, but the way he told them always made me laugh. Then he got transferred to the camp and nothing was very funny anymore.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Did he ever discuss with you what went on there? What his duties included?

speaker: MRS. MCALPIN
line: No. He'd just come home angry, mostly at himself though sometimes he'd turn it on Luke and me.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Was he ever treated for depression or stress?

speaker: MRS. MCALPIN
line: No. I tried getting him to talk to someone, even our minister, but Jack believed in dealing with his own problems.

speaker: MULDER
line: Did he believe in voodoo?

speaker: MRS. MCALPIN
line: The Marines, his family and football pretty much sums up everything Jack believed in.

speaker: MULDER
line: So, when did you first think that his death involved something out of the ordinary?

speaker: MRS. MCALPIN
line: One of the boys in his squad told me what they found at the accident and he said it was some kind of voodoo curse -- the same one they found on the stool that Puerto Rican boy used to hang himself.

speaker: MULDER
line: Who told you that?

speaker: MRS. MCALPIN
line: Harry Dunham. He's from New Orleans so he's pretty superstitious about that type of thing.

speaker: MULDER
line: What about you?

speaker: MRS. MCALPIN
line: My husband had just died so I didn't give it much thought either way... Not until Luke dug this up out of his sandbox.

speaker: MRS. MCALPIN
line: I know it sounds crazy me worrying about all this but the truth is, I'm scared. I'm scared for my child... And I just don't know what to do anymore.

speaker: CHESTER
line: Go! Go! Get away! Get away! He’s crazy. Too much rum. For such a pretty lady it’s dangerous out here. You need something pour vous gardez --- for protection. Your lucky charm.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Come on, Mulder.

speaker: MULDER
line: How much?

speaker: CHESTER
line: Five … Ten.

speaker: MULDER
line: I’ll give you five.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Let’s go, Mulder.

speaker: MULDER
line: You should always carry protection. Hold on. There you go.

speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
line: I'm still not clear just what it is you're investigating here.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Two of your men have died in the past two weeks allegedly of self-inflicted injuries.

speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
line: And I've taken every measure to see it doesn't happen again. I've even flown in the 528th combat stress control detachment from Camp LeJeune.

speaker: SCULLY
line: But your soldiers aren't in combat.

speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
line: In some ways what we're dealing with here is worse.

speaker: SCULLY
line: How so?

speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
line: We're soldiers. We're not prison guards. And we're being asked to police a hostile population of foreigners without the resources to feed or house them. There are bound to be some conflicts.

speaker: SCULLY
line: So your men are getting the brunt of the refugees' frustration?

speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
line: It's hatred, plain and simple. They hate us and all I can do is see that they're processed as efficiently as possible.

speaker: MULDER
line: Colonel Wharton, a, uh... A certain ritual sign was found at the scene of both deaths. Is there anything you can tell us about that?

speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
line: Not much. Apparently, it's some sort of voodoo marking.

speaker: MULDER
line: But you haven't investigated it as a possibility.

speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
line: Possibility of what? All I know is voodoo caused a riot in my camp. One night they held some secret ceremony. The next day all hell broke loose.

speaker: MULDER
line: We understand a refugee was killed-- a young boy.

speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
line: No one felt that tragedy more deeply than me. Fortunately, I was able to isolate the one responsible for instigating all the trouble.

speaker: MULDER
line: Who would that be?

speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
line: His name is Bauvais. Pierre Bauvais. Thinks he's some kind of revolutionary.

speaker: MULDER
line: Do you think we could speak with him?

speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
line: If you don't mind listening to his laundry list of complaints.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I'd also like to examine Private McAlpin's body. I have a signed consent from his wife.

speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
line: Private Dunham will help you with whatever you need.

speaker: CORONER FOYLE
line: Cause of death was no great mystery. That boy was doing 60 when he hit the tree.

speaker: SCULLY
line: So they pronounced him at the scene?

speaker: CORONER FOYLE
line: His head was hanging on his shoulders like a broken peony and he had no respiratory or cardiac functioning. I saw no reason to conduct an autopsy then and I still don't. Well, you can see for yourself.

speaker: CORONER FOYLE
line: What kind of a sick joke is this? Jackson!

speaker: JACKSON
line: Sir?

speaker: CORONER FOYLE
line: Who the hell's been in here?! Someone’s tampered with McAlpin’s body and I want to know who!

speaker: MULDER
line: You’re Harry Dunham.

speaker: PRIVATE DUNHAM
line: Yes, sir.

speaker: MULDER
line: You knew Private McAlpin? His wife said you were friends.

speaker: PRIVATE DUNHAM
line: We were in the same squad.

speaker: MULDER
line: Any idea why he might have killed himself?

speaker: PRIVATE DUNHAM
line: I can't say, sir.

speaker: MULDER
line: You can't say or you won't say?

speaker: PRIVATE DUNHAM
line: I'll be right here if you need me.

speaker: MULDER
line: My name is Mulder. I'm with the FBI. I was hoping you could answer some questions about the two US Marines who took their own lives.

speaker: BAUVAIS
line: It is a terrible shame.

speaker: MULDER
line: I'm not convinced it's as simple as that.

speaker: BAUVAIS
line: You do not believe I was involved in this, do you? How could I be... When they keep me locked up in here?

speaker: MULDER
line: You tell me. These photographs were taken at the sites of both deaths. The shell was found buried under one of the soldiers' homes. Can you tell me about the symbol?

speaker: BAUVAIS
line: Why? What do you expect to learn from this?

speaker: MULDER
line: Just the truth. One of the Marines left behind a wife. She's too frightened to even mourn. She deserves some peace of mind.

speaker: BAUVAIS
line: It is the Loco-Miroir the crossroads between the two worlds-- the mirror in which a man must confront his true self. These Marines... Maybe they didn't like what they saw.

speaker: MULDER
line: Colonel Wharton says you incited the riot last month.

speaker: BAUVAIS
line: My country was born on the blood of slaves. Freedom is our most sacred legacy.

speaker: MULDER
line: Does that mean you would kill to preserve it?

speaker: BAUVAIS
line: Wharton will not let us return home... Which is all we ask.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, I need to speak with you.

speaker: BAUVAIS
line: She’s come to tell you the Marine is gone.

speaker: SCULLY
line: How did you know?

speaker: BAUVAIS
line: It’s the spirits. The Loa have warned you.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Somebody stole McAlpin's body and replaced it with what looks like a dog's corpse.

speaker: BAUVAIS
line: They will only warn you once. After that, no magic can save you.

speaker: MULDER
line: Come on, Scully. Let's go.

speaker: MULDER
line: So what do you think happened to Private McAlpin?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Somehow, Bauvais must have switched the bodies.

speaker: MULDER
line: It's quite a trick considering he's been confined for the last month.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, then he had somebody else do it.

speaker: MULDER
line: But you said there was no trace evidence. And security is practically impossible to breach.

speaker: SCULLY
line: I was only suggesting that whoever did it was clever and thorough. I wasn’t suggesting that some kind of spirit did it.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, just in case, I believe in covering my bases.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, voodoo only works by instilling fear in its believers. You saw how Bauvais tried to intimidate me. I'll admit the power of suggestion is considerable but this is no more magic than a pair of fuzzy dice.

speaker: MULDER
line: Scully, look out!

speaker: MULDER
line: Hey...

speaker: SCULLY
line: Private McAlpin?

speaker: SCULLY
line: He’s nonverbal, nonresponsive to voice, touch or pain. The neurologists suspect he suffered a severe concussion resulting in amnesia.

speaker: MULDER
line: It’s a plausible diagnosis. Only I'm more interested in how he came back to life.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, obviously, he never left. Dr. Foyle made a gross mistake when he signed the death certificate. It’s not the first time something like that’s happened.

speaker: MULDER
line: Did you get a copy of the blood test?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yeah. Electrolytes, white and red counts are all normal. Except this is strange. The lab detected trace levels of tetrodotoxin in his blood. That's a poison found in the liver and reproductive organs of puffer fish-- a Japanese delicacy.

speaker: MULDER
line: Somehow, I get the feeling Private McAlpin didn't frequent too many sushi bars.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You have a theory how it got into his blood?

speaker: MULDER
line: What do you know about zombies?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, I hope you don't intend to tell Robin McAlpin that she married one?

speaker: MULDER
line: In 1982, a Harvard ethnobotanist named Wade Davis did extensive field research in Haiti on the zombification phenomenon. He analyzed several samples of zombie powder prepared by voodoo priests and he found tetrodotoxin to be common to all of them.

speaker: SCULLY
line: But, Mulder, it’s a lethal poison.

speaker: MULDER
line: But in small enough doses it can cause paralysis and depress cardiorespiratory activities to such a low level that the victim might appear clinically dead.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, zombie or not, Jack McAlpin is alive.

speaker: MULDER
line: Exactly. Which is what makes me wonder about the other Marine who allegedly killed himself.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Why did they bury Private Guttierez here?

speaker: GROUNDSKEEPER
line: They beat you to it. You're the FBI, aren't you? Stay. Easy, Wong.

speaker: MULDER
line: Yeah. We've arranged to exhume the body of Manuel Guttierez.

speaker: GROUNDSKEEPER
line: Right. The Marine. I prepared the dig as soon as I got the judge's order, but it's too late.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Too late?

speaker: GROUNDSKEEPER
line: Yeah. The body snatchers got there first. I caught them more than few times right in the act but it's getting I can't keep up anymore. That's, uh, why I got this.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Don't the police intervene?

speaker: GROUNDSKEEPER
line: They got their hands full trying to protect the lives of the living. I am all these people have to preserve their rest.

speaker: MULDER
line: These body snatchers … What do they do with the bodies?

speaker: GROUNDSKEEPER
line: Ah, they sell them.

speaker: MULDER
line: To who?

speaker: GROUNDSKEEPER
line: Well, it varies. When the local medical school ran short of cadavers rumor had it that the snatchers got $200 a head. But mostly, it's the voodoo types who do the buying. A lot of folks in these parts go in for that with the medicines and the potions and... Yeah, here we are.

speaker: GROUNDSKEEPER
line: Look at that. They dug him up right under my nose. How’s he supposed to rest in peace like this? They can do what they like with the pigs and the chickens but this is a desecration. This is uncool.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder ..

speaker: GROUNDSKEEPER
line: Look at that. See what I’m talking about?

speaker: MULDER
line: Let us take care of this.

speaker: GROUNDSKEEPER
line: Knock yourselves out.

speaker: CHESTER
line: Let me be! I didn't do nothing! What did I do?

speaker: MULDER
line: Maybe you can tell us.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Maybe I should kiss a few and find out if one is Guttierez.

speaker: CHESTER
line: Fresh bones. They pay good. But I go there for the frogs. You find the best frogs at the cemetery.

speaker: SCULLY
line: How do you get out of the camp?

speaker: CHESTER
line: I go, and then I come back.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What about your parents? Are your parents at the camp?

speaker: MULDER
line: What about a name?

speaker: CHESTER
line: Chester Bonaparte.

speaker: MULDER
line: What do you do with the frogs, Chester?

speaker: CHESTER
line: For each one I catch, I get 50 cents.

speaker: MULDER
line: From who? Who pays you for them?

speaker: CHESTER
line: Bauvais. His magic is the most strong. He even made my fries disappear.

speaker: MULDER
line: Hey, Chester. I got magic, too, and I bet I can make your fries reappear.

speaker: CHESTER
line: Merci!

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, certain frog species secrete a substance called bufotoxin. It's chemically similar to what we found in Private McAlpin’s blood. I think we should ask Bauvais what he's doing with those frogs.

speaker: MULDER
line: I didn't want to say anything before because I wasn't sure, but I think we're being followed. It's a gray four-door sedan in the parking lot. Keep an eye on Chester.

speaker: MULDER
line: Out of the car, Private. You've been following us.

speaker: PRIVATE DUNHAM
line: Look, I had to warn you.

speaker: MULDER
line: You didn’t seem too interested in helping us before.

speaker: PRIVATE DUNHAM
line: I couldn't talk then-- not with Colonel Wharton so close by. And not with him right there.

speaker: MULDER
line: Chester? He's just a little boy.

speaker: PRIVATE DUNHAM
line: No, sir, he is not.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What’s going on?

speaker: MULDER
line: Private Dunham was just about to tell us why we're in danger.

speaker: PRIVATE DUNHAM
line: You're putting yourselves into the middle of something you don't understand.

speaker: MULDER
line: But you do?

speaker: PRIVATE DUNHAM
line: Bauvais warned him. He told the Colonel he'd take his men one by one unless...

speaker: MULDER
line: Unless what?

speaker: PRIVATE DUNHAM
line: Unless the Colonel let his people go back to Haiti. But the Colonel... He just had us turn up the heat on all them beatings and all.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Colonel Wharton sanctioned beatings of the refugees?

speaker: PRIVATE DUNHAM
line: He ordered it, and worse. The things he is making us do to those people.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Why hasn't anybody stepped forward or filed a complaint?

speaker: PRIVATE DUNHAM
line: None of us feel good about it, Ma’am, but you don't join the Marines to feel good.

speaker: MULDER
line: You said that Bauvais threatened the Colonel’s men.

speaker: PRIVATE DUNHAM
line: He said he'd take their souls.

speaker: MULDER
line: You believe he can do that?

speaker: PRIVATE DUNHAM
line: Jack was my friend, and look what happened to him.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Well, we don't know what happened to him but there is a medical explanation for his condition.

speaker: PRIVATE DUNHAM
line: Back home, an associate of my daddy's, Clyde Jessamin, once crossed a man on some kind of real estate deal. And not two weeks passed before Jessamin's daughter took ill with something the doctors couldn't make heads or tails of. All they could do was shoot her full of morphine the pain was so bad. She died five minutes past midnight on her wedding day, and when they did an autopsy to try and figure it out, all they could find was a bunch of snakes squirming around inside her belly.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Sounds like an old wives’ tale.

speaker: PRIVATE DUNHAM
line: No, Ma’am. It’s not. You see, I’m the one who was supposed to marry her.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Think he’s telling the truth?

speaker: MULDER
line: Till I can figure out why he’d lie, yeah.

speaker: SCULLY
line: He’s superstitious, and superstition breeds fear. It’s what Voodoo is all about. It’s just as irrational as avoiding a crack in the sidewalk.

speaker: MULDER
line: Why would he be trying to avoid Chester?

speaker: MULDER
line: Chester? Chester?

speaker: MULDER
line: Chester! Chester! Stop! I’m not going to hurt you! It’s okay. I’ll get him. Chester! Chester!

speaker: PRIVATE KITTEL
line: Can I get you anything else, sir?

speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
line: Just get the door.

speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
line: I’m sorry. I’m having my breakfast.

speaker: MULDER
line: That’s all right. We already ate.

speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
line: I understand you obtained a court order yesterday to exhume Private Guttierez.

speaker: MULDER
line: That’s right.

speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
line: You should know I filed a complaint with the Justice Department.

speaker: MULDER
line: His body was missing-- stolen from his coffin apparently.

speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
line: Now you see what we're facing here. What kind of barbaric religion would desecrate a grave?

speaker: SCULLY
line: We suspect it was an act of retaliation.

speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
line: Retaliation?

speaker: SCULLY
line: For your mistreatment of the detainees.

speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
line: What the hell are you talking about?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Physical abuse of political refugees is a prosecutable crime under international law.

speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
line: It's Bauvais, isn't it? He's the one you're getting this garbage from. Look, nobody ever said this was a hotel but it's hardly a concentration camp.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Then there is no official policy of harassment?

speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
line: If anything, it’s my men who are being harassed. The UN, the relief organizations, they’re all so busy protecting the rights of these refugees nobody’s looking out for my men.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, we’ll let you finish. Wouldn’t want your breakfast to get cold.

speaker: MULDER
line: Wharton’s left these people no choice but to fight back with the only weapon they have.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Sorry, Mulder, there’s a big difference between nasty looks and raising the dead.

speaker: MULDER
line: Not according to Private Dunham.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Ah!!!

speaker: MULDER
line: What?

speaker: SCULLY
line: More scare tactics.

speaker: MULDER
line: Let me see that.

speaker: SCULLY
line: No. It’s nothing.

speaker: PRIVATE KITTEL
line: I don't think he's in any condition to talk.

speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
line: That's right, Private. You don't think. You follow orders.

speaker: PRIVATE KITTEL
line: But sir...

speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
line: You're dismissed.

speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
line: Ouvri barriere pou' moi. I want the secret. Maybe you should tell me now while you can still talk.

speaker: BAUVAIS
line: Ma vie nan mains bon dieu..

speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
line: No, papaloi. Your life is in my hands.

speaker: MULDER
line: I was surprised to get your card. I had assumed our last contact... would be our last. Why are you here?

speaker: X
line: Your investigation is faltering, Agent Mulder.

speaker: MULDER
line: I've got a renegade Marine who may be violating every human rights provision...

speaker: X
line: These people have no rights. In 24 hours all access to Folkstone will be restricted to military personnel. No press, no third-party monitoring.

speaker: MULDER
line: What about Scully and me?

speaker: X
line: You'll be called back to Washington on a priority matter.

speaker: MULDER
line: They're making the camp invisible. Why?

speaker: X
line: In case you haven't noticed, Agent Mulder, the Statue of Liberty is on vacation. The new mandate says if you're not a citizen you'd better keep out.

speaker: MULDER
line: Why hold them up? Why not just repatriate them?

speaker: X
line: During our most recent involvement in Haiti three US soldiers took their own lives. Of those men, two were under Colonel Wharton's command.

speaker: MULDER
line: You’re saying the military's sanctioning Wharton's revenge? These people are innocent civilians. Some people in Congress might have a real problem with that.

speaker: X
line: By the time they get a committee together it'll be as if none of this ever happened.

speaker: SCULLY
line: You don't understand. I've been on hold for half an hour. I'm trying to locate a Private Dunham.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yeah. Yeah. Thanks.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, I just got through to Dunham’s barracks. Mulder? Your door's unlocked.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder, listen to this. Dunham's been AWOL since last night...

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Oh, God.

speaker: MULDER
line: Scully?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yeah.

speaker: MULDER
line: I found him wandering around outside. You all right?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Yeah. It's Dunham.

speaker: MULDER
line: When I found him. He had this in his hand.

speaker: MULDER
line: Do you recall leaving the hospital?

speaker: PRIVATE MCALPIN
line: These past few days I don't recall much of anything... Except feeling real heavy like I’m asleep and I can't wake up.

speaker: MULDER
line: Do you remember killing Private Dunham?

speaker: PRIVATE MCALPIN
line: All I remember is being there seeing him in all that blood.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Why did you sign the confession?

speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
line: The Private asked and I apprised him of what you found at the crime scene.

speaker: PRIVATE MCALPIN
line: Who else might it have been?

speaker: MULDER
line: Colonel... Can we have a word outside?

speaker: MULDER
line: What exactly did you tell him?

speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
line: If you're suggesting that I coerced Private McAlpin...

speaker: MULDER
line: I need to know that he signed that confession voluntarily?

speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
line: Of course he did.

speaker: MULDER
line: Since his … reappearance has Private McAlpin had any contact with Bauvais?

speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
line: Not to my knowledge.

speaker: MULDER
line: Well, we'd still like to speak with Bauvais.

speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
line: I'm afraid that's impossible.

speaker: MULDER
line: Why?

speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
line: Because he's dead. Last night he cut his wrists with a bedspring. I'll have the report sent to your motel along with the Private's confession. Since both matters are being handled internally I’ll assume your business here is finished.

speaker: MULDER
line: What's wrong?

speaker: SCULLY
line: I'm fine. It's just a headache.

speaker: MULDER
line: Mulder. …….. Okay, Mrs. McAlpin. We can be there in fifteen minutes.

speaker: MRS. MCALPIN
line: First I thought I lost him... As if that wasn't hard enough to deal with. Now they're saying he's killed Harry.

speaker: SCULLY
line: He said it himself. He signed a confession.

speaker: MRS. MCALPIN
line: I don't care. It doesn't make sense. Jack and Harry were friends.

speaker: MULDER
line: Mrs. McAlpin, you said on the telephone that Private Dunham came here last night. What did he want?

speaker: MRS. MCALPIN
line: He was on his way to see you.

speaker: MULDER
line: For what reason?

speaker: MRS. MCALPIN
line: He wouldn't tell me. He said if anything happened to him... I should give this to you. He told me not to open it.

speaker: MRS. MCALPIN
line: Luke's been in a mood since all this started. It's almost like he knows what's going on. I'll be right back.

speaker: SCULLY
line: That’s Bauvais. And Wharton? They must have known each other when Wharton served in Haiti.

speaker: MULDER
line: When in Rome …

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder … Dunham and Guttierez both filed complaints against Colonel Wharton. They both cited incidents of abuse --- dates, times …

speaker: MULDER
line: Scully …. Look at this. Check out the name on the dogtags.

speaker: PRIVATE KITTEL
line: Come with me, please. Take the light out of my eyes.

speaker: MULDER
line: Where’s Wharton?

speaker: PRIVATE KITTEL
line: You’ll find out soon enough.

speaker: MULDER
line: He killed Bauvais. If you know anything about it you’ll be tried as an accessory to murder…

speaker: PRIVATE KITTEL
line: Shut up! Bauvais got what he deserved. After what he did to McAlpin and Guttierez?

speaker: SCULLY
line: It wasn’t Bauvais.

speaker: PRIVATE KITTEL
line: What are you talking about?

speaker: SCULLY
line: Those men were about to testify against Colonel Wharton. He stopped them before they did.

speaker: MULDER
line: If you don’t believe us, look in the trunk.

speaker: MULDER
line: This is what’s left of Private Guttierez. Now where’s Bauvais’ body?

speaker: PRIVATE KITTEL
line: We buried him … this afternoon .. in the municipal graveyard.

speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
line: Au nom de saints… et de la lune. Au nom de saints… et de la lune. Au nom de saints et des etoilles.

speaker: MULDER
line: What is it, Scully?

speaker: SCULLY
line: I’m all right.

speaker: MULDER
line: You don’t look all right.

speaker: SCULLY
line: No, I’m fine. I’ll catch up with you. Just go get Wharton.

speaker: MULDER
line: Federal Agent! Drop the knife, Wharton.

speaker: COLONEL WHARTON
line: nan

speaker: MULDER
line: Drop the knife!

speaker: MULDER
line: Ah!!!

speaker: BAUVAIS
line: Ca qui fait mal, ce mal li we. He who does evil, evil he will see.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Mulder …

speaker: MULDER
line: You’re okay?

speaker: SCULLY
line: I feel better than you look.

speaker: SCULLY
line: What happened?

speaker: MULDER
line: I don’t know.

speaker: SCULLY
line: He’s dead. Did you kill him?

speaker: MULDER
line: No. It was Bauvais.

speaker: SOLDIER
line: Here’s the passenger manifest you asked for.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Thank you.

speaker: SOLDIER
line: They’re petitioning to have Bauvais returned to Haiti.

speaker: MULDER
line: Too bad it has to be in a box.

speaker: SCULLY
line: Is this a complete list?

speaker: SOLDIER
line: As far as I know.

speaker: SCULLY
line: There was a boy. His name was Bonaparte. Chester Bonaparte?

speaker: SOLDIER
line: Poor kid. He died six weeks ago in that riot.
